So, continuing my obsession with Minmus, I have equipped Khoine Base MK.2 with 2 "FlyingSaucer" transporters. Essentially, they are a .625 RCS tank, surrounded by spherical RCS tanks, with flat 1.25 - .625 adapters on top to make a saucer shape. They are propelled by RCS, and can fly over Minmus and skim the ground. A kerbal is seated on top.

I use my FlyingSaucers to get EVA reports and samples from areas I cannot drive or fly the base to.

Do you use personal kerbal transporters? For what?
I have an assemblage of struts that can get kerbals off of Eve with no fuel.. Probably one of its best uses.

So, continuing my obsession with Minmus, I have equipped Khoine Base MK.2 with 2 "FlyingSaucer" transporters. Essentially, they are a .625 RCS tank, surrounded by spherical RCS tanks, with flat 1.25 - .625 adapters on top to make a saucer shape. They are propelled by RCS, and can fly over Minmus and skim the ground. A kerbal is seated on top.

I use my FlyingSaucers to get EVA reports and samples from areas I cannot drive or fly the base to.

Do you use personal kerbal transporters? For what?

I wanted too, but decided that such a device sounded like a Kerbal killer when my usual inability to accurately use RCS thrusters is taken into account. So instead of a command seat, I used a probe core on top of two small cylindrical RCS tanks, weighed it down with the smaller science equipment and the tiny landing legs and attached it to the top of my usual Minmus lander.

It worked. Basically. Sort of. I did something wrong with the docking ports and couldn't re-attach the probe. On the other hand, I flew it around and collected lots of science which I then had Jeb and crew collect before they blasted off, leaving the probe on Minmus, resting on its side cuz it's leg footprint was way too narrow. In retrospect, I wish I had used the spherical tanks alongside the cylindrical ones to provide a wider landing footprint like I assume you did.

I may try that for the next mission...the spherical tanks might shorten it too...it was so tall it my lander a bit more wobbly than usual as I designed it.
